article:
In Christianity, an 'apostolic see' is any episcopal see whose foundation is
attributed to one or more of the apostles of Jesus.

Out of the many such sees, five acquired special importance in Chalcedonian
Christianity (beginning with the council held in 451) and became classified as
the Pentarchy in Eastern Orthodox Christianity. But before then, the First
Council of Nicaea of 325 recognized in its sixth canon the special position of
Rome and Alexandria, and perhaps of Antioch and the chief sees in other
provinces: "The ancient customs of Egypt, Libya and Pentapolis shall be
maintained, according to which the bishop of Alexandria has authority over all
these places since a similar custom exists with reference to the bishop of Rome.
Similarly in Antioch and the other provinces the prerogatives of the churches
are to be preserved." [http://www.ewtn.com/library/COUNCILS/NICAEA1.HTM#3
Canons of the First Council of Nicaea] And Jerusalem received special
recognition in the seventh
canon. [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf214.vii.vi.x.html Schaff's Seven
Ecumenical Councils: First Nicaea: Canon VII]: "Since custom and ancient
tradition have prevailed that the Bishop of Aelia [i.e., Jerusalem] should be
honoured, let him, saving its due dignity to the Metropolis, have the next place
of honour."; "It is very hard to determine just what was the "precedence"
granted to the Bishop of Aelia, nor is it clear which is the metropolis referred
to in the last clause. Most writers, including Hefele, Balsamon, Aristenus and
Beveridge consider it to be CÃ¦sarea; while Zonaras thinks Jerusalem to be
intended, a view recently adopted and defended by Fuchs; others again suppose it
is Antioch that is referred to." The Council, which was held in 325, of
course made no mention of Constantinople, a city which was founded and became
the capital of the empire only in 330. [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-
mY7McxJl7jYC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Constantinople+founded+330&source=bl&ots=doZ-
Wox6y4o&sig=WR2PbvzmCW_RaYlx5Y9sBAQ5EYU&hl=en&ei=LLGvSrbXLoqt4gaS0PGsCg&sa=X&oi-
=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#v=onepage&q=Constantinople%20founded%20330&f=f-
alse Robin W. Winks, World Civilization: A Brief History (Rowman & Littlefield
Publishers 1993 ISBN 978-0-939693-28-3), p. 120] [http://www.worldtimelines.org.uk/world/europe/south_east/AD400-
800 Timelines: Southeast
Europe] [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04301a.htm Catholic
Encyclopedia, article Constantinople] Officially, Constantinople was
founded on 11 May 330. Commemorative coins that were issued during the 330s
already refer to the city as Constantinopolis (see e.g. Michael Grant, The
climax of Rome (London 1968), p. 133), or "Constantine's City". According to the
Reallexikon fÃ¼r Antike und Christentum, vol. 164 (Stuttgart 2005), column 442,
there is no evidence for the tradition that Constantine officially dubbed the
city "New Rome" (Nova Roma). It is possible that the emperor called the city
"Second Rome" (, DeutÃ©ra RhÅmÄ) by official decree, as reported by the 5th-
century church historian Socrates of Constantinople: see Names of
Constantinople. Constantine the Great (who died on 22 May 337) divided the
expanded city (previously known as Byzantium), like Rome, into 14 regions, and
ornamented it with public works worthy of an imperial metropolis. A
description can be found in the Notitia urbis Constantinopolitanae. The
First Council of Constantinople (381) decreed in a canon of disputed validity:
"The Bishop of Constantinople, however, shall have the prerogative of honour
after the Bishop of Rome; because Constantinople is New
Rome." [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf214.ix.viii.iv.html Canon
3] A century after the Council of Chalcedon (451) and the ensuing schism
between those who accepted it and those who rejected it, the theory of the
Pentarchy was given expression: "formulated in the legislation of the emperor
Justinian I (527â565), especially in his Novella 131, the theory received formal
ecclesiastical sanction at the Council in Trullo (692), which ranked the five
sees as Rome, Constantinople, Alexandria, Antioch, and Jerusalem." [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-
9059117/pentarchy Encyclopaedia Britannica: Pentarchy]

The bishops of these five sees consider themselves to be successors of those
indicated in the following list:
* Rome, in Italy (Saint Peter and Saint Paul)
* Constantinople, now Istanbul in present-day Turkey (Saint Andrew)
* Alexandria, in Egypt (Saint Mark the Evangelist) Saint Mark is not called
  an apostle in the New Testament, but he is said to have been one of the
  Seventy Apostles and to have been commissioned as an apostle when he
  accompanied Saint Paul and Saint Barnabas in their apostolic journeys.
* Antioch, in present-day Turkey (Saint Peter).
* Jerusalem, in the Holy Land (Saint Peter and Saint James)

Other sees who claim to be founded by an apostle and thus can claim to be
apostolic sees include:
* the Archdiocese of Athens, Greece (Saint Paul)
* Ephesus, in present-day Turkey (John the Apostle)
* Seleucia-Ctesiphon, near modern Baghdad and the ruins of ancient Babylon in
  present-day Iraq (Thomas the Apostle, Bartholomew the Apostle, and Thaddeus
  of Edessa)
* Aquileia, in northeastern Italy (Mark the Evangelist as one of the
  Seventy Apostles)
* See of Milan, in northwestern Italy (Barnabas the Apostle)
* See of Syracuse, in Sicily (Peter)
* Philippi, in Greece (Saint Paul)
* Thessaloniki, in Greece (Saint
  Paul) [http://books.google.com/books?id=oP3k4TNiDWMC Craig A. Evans,The
  Bible Knowledge Background Commentary: Acts-Philemon] (David C. Cook, 2004),
  p. 610)
* Corinth, in Greece (Saint
  Paul) [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/robertson_at/wp_2cor.xi.html A.T.
  Robertson, Word Pictures in the New Testament - 2 Corinthians]
* Malta (Saint Paul)
* Paphos, in Cyprus (Barnabas and Paul)
* Armenian Apostolic Church (Thaddeaus (Jude the Apostle) and Bartholomew
  the Apostle)
* Saint Thomas Christians in India (Thomas the Apostle)
